title: 115_s702
content: The "Preventing Labor Union Slowdowns Act of 2017" or the "PLUS Act" aims to deter labor slowdowns. The National Labor Relations Act is amended to address labor slowdowns in the maritime industry at US ports to maintain competitiveness in the global economy. The slowdowns at US ports have caused significant economic disruptions, affecting domestic and international commerce. This has led to a threat to the economic health of the United States and its businesses. The policy is to eliminate these disruptions and provide remedies to those affected. The bill aims to address labor slowdowns at US ports by providing effective remedies to individuals affected by such disruptions. It defines terms related to employee engagement in maritime employment and labor slowdowns to clarify the scope of the legislation. In section 8(b) (29 U.S.C. 158(b)), amendments are made to paragraphs (6) and (7), and a new paragraph (8) is added regarding labor slowdowns in maritime employment representation. Section 10(l) (29 U.S.C. 160(l)) is also amended to include references to the new paragraph (8) of section 8(b). Additionally, Section 303 of the Labor Management Relations Act, 1947 (29 U.S.C. 187) is amended to address labor slowdowns at US ports. Section 303 of the Labor Management Relations Act, 1947 is amended to address damages for unfair labor practices under section 8(b)(8) of the National Labor Relations Act. Damages recovered will be double the amount sustained, including attorney and expert witness fees. In actions for damages resulting from violations of section 8(b)(8), waivers of rights by the injured party will not be a defense. The amendment to Section 303 of the Labor Management Relations Act, 1947 addresses damages for unfair labor practices under section 8(b)(8) of the National Labor Relations Act. Waivers of rights by the injured party will not be a defense in pursuing monetary damages related to labor slowdowns.
